The service was very good and the food was delicious
We had the dish with braised chicken and also got the tomato pizza
Both dishes were well cooked 
The server checked on us a few times asking if we want something else
Overall I enjoyed the experience there and will go back there
The only drawback was that they didn't have any warm vegetarian dish except for salads and soups
author: Farshid G.

description:
I loved this popular yet refreshingly simple, pleasantly understated little french bistro.  The service was awesome and they have a great rear yard patio for outdoor table dining with a giant fresco of the downtown San Francisco skyline fused with Van Gogh's Starry Night as the background on the side wall.  Really neat.

The food is remarkable as well; I had the grilled lamb steak, which had all the great tender texture and succulence of good lamb without that gamey, lambey flavor that lamb often tends to have (especially in middle eastern places). It came with a delicious sauteed spinach with garlic and some au gratin potatoes.  My date had the lobster raviolis which were also quite good.  For dessert we shared the rustic apple pie a la mode with caramel drizzled on it - insanely delicious.

This restaurant would have merited five stars, but for the fact that by 8:30 on a Friday night, they had run out of four items that we were interested in ordering, including some of their most popular dishes.  Come earlier in the evening to be assured of getting what you want here....
author: Rick H.

description:
OMG! this really hot guy brought me to this really hot spot in the marina!  We met at singles Safeway!  Okay, seriously it is in the marina but by no means marina-typical (over-priced and mediocre).    

Bistro Aix was fantastic!  We sat on a covered patio filling ourselves silly with homemade focaccia.  Definitely the best I've ever had.  
We selected from the prix fixe menu and each started with a nice mesclun green salad.  The warm breaded goat cheese really made the salad amazing.  I could have eaten 5 more!  
For dinner, I had the sea bass and mussels bouillabaise and he had the top sirloin.  They were both delicious!  I don't usually like sirloin cuts but Aix made it perfectly. It was melt-in-your-mouth tender and juicy... and for medium-well that's hard to do.  The bouillabaise sauce was a little too rich, but still great.  I ate every last bite.
We finished with the crme brulee and it was just as great as the rest of the meal.  
Great atmosphere and great food. I am definitely coming back.
Thank you to my perfect date for picking Bistro Aix!
author: Lauren C.

description:
I think this place is Isa's cousin. They look so much alike! We had a seat on the patio. (Just like Isas) Even in late December it was warm thanks to the heaters. (Just like Isas) The twinkling lights were gorgeous, (Just like Isas) but the all the walls were covered in rather amatuer-ish looking paintings. (Thankfully not like Isa's) 

Our waitress was super friendly and helpful. I was particularly impressed when she stayed exactly in our price range when we asked for help with the wine list. I am sad to say I forgot what we picked, but it was delicious and paired perfectly with our pastas. Speaking of, both were wonderfully flavored. The bill was fantastic too - Entrees for 2 and a bottle of wine was $60, including tip!
author: Kelly C.

description:
Truly a great dining experience! We were a table of 5. I ordered the Ahi as I'd read a recommendation. It was perfect. The port reduction was outstanding. Two had the leg of lamb, which was med-rare as ordered. All of us received crispy spinach which we found delicious and really different. One had a steak and another had an aioli hamburger on the most wonderful focaccia bread. 
We shared two orders of perfect, crispy calamari with some tasty slaw and cilantro. For dessert we shared a chocolate cloud cake and and a serving of ice cream with a chocolate and almond sauce.  Even the decaffeinated coffee was outstanding. 
Ben was our server. He was totally responsive and engaged without ever hovering or interrupting our conversations. When we requested lowering the volume on the music b/c the speakers were over our table, he graciously accommodated.)
Diners at next table raved about their scallops. 
This was one of my 2 favorite restaurant experiences ever! I hope to return soon.
author: Casey S.

description:
Even though I knew this place was Chronicle Top 100 it still exceeded my expectations and totally impressed me. It's cute, totally unassuming in the Marina... (not filled with the Marina crowd) and the food was amazing, especially for the price!

4 people got: a bottle of wine, 4 starters, 4 main dishes and 2 shared desserts.... bill split 4 ways... $55 each!

What I know is good: sirloin, crab angel hair pasta and ahi tuna. I got the sirloin and they let me mix and match sides with other main dishes which was totally sweet.

If Bistro Aix is on your list, move it to the top. If it's not, add it.... to the top.
author: Derek B.

description:
This place is a bit pricey for me, but since my aunt was taking me out to dinner here I abadoned all caution and ordered freely.  While everything was really good, I wasn't totally blown away by the food.  I had the ahi tuna with mashed potatoes and fried baby spinach.  The thing I discovered about fried baby spinach is that, while it sounds intriguing on a menu, it is actually a boring, and slightly annoying way to prepare spinach.  It didn't really have any flavor, and the texture of the spinach was thrown off to the point where it just sort of stuck to the front of my teeth.  (This phenomenon could be entirely my fault, however.  Anyone who knows me will recall that I have an uncanny ability get food stuck in odd parts of my teeth.)  The rest of the meal was tasty, though, and the bread and wine before the meal was great.      

Other factors that give Bistro Aix a four star rating:
1.  This is a pricey restaurant, but it does not necessarily have to be.  They have a few options that are around $10 (instead of $20 for the entrees) and wallets always appreciate that.
2. The service is excellent.  We had about three different people from the wait staff helping our table at one point or another and they were all friendly, helpful, and attentive. 
3. The atmosphere of the restaurant is really nice.  Not too dark, not too crowded, not too loud.   You can almost forget you are in the Marina.
author: Caroline H.

description:
I went to Bistro Aix last night on the recommendation of friend and fellow Yelper Chris B.  He never steers me wrong in the restaurant department (but don't listen to a word he says about dry cleaners...).  This was no exception.

The service was excellent (our waiter even opened up some by-the-bottle sauvignon blanc for my friend when her original by-the-glass selection was unavailable) and friendly in that warm-but-not-in-your-face way.  I loved my french onion soup - rich and sweet  - I almost demanded another bowl!

My only whine - most of the wines on the list were not french, which I would have expected.
author: Suzanne B.

description: Food was good, not superb. But I did like the ambiance and the service was very good. I went there with a friend and seating was comfortable but it may not be ideal for large groups. And, I was there week night so it may be crowded in the weekends. Check other reviews. :)
author: nuri g.

description:
Clearly the people you are with make or break a location, and the people that joined me for my first visit to Aix made me ADORE this little bistro.  Since you're probably not cool, charming, or important enough to have friends like mine, I'll have to review other parts of the restaurant that you can attempt to replicate.  But honestly, you'll never truly be me.

We sat out on the back patio which was the perfect temperature even for a cool SF night.  The food wasn't mind blowing, but it was certainly good.  They had plenty of specials to choose from along with the full menu itself.  I don't eat red meat and I was with a REAL vegetarian and neither of us had any problem finding tasty eats.  I had the ahi (I can never turn down ahi) with some CRAZY good mashed potatoes and spinach.  I'd love to go back and try the prix fixe menu.

Oh, and we were totally "that loud obnoxious table" but the sound level seemed really reasonable (even with our racket).  It's definitely a good place to go if you want to actually be able to talk.  As one of my dining companions said at the end of the meal "this is what my parents meant when they used to say they were going out with their friends for dinner to talk... now I get it."  So true, so true.
author: Caitlin D.

description:
We have been here several times, including last night; basically food is good until the last  part of the evening when we asked for coffee and it came out cold;we asked for a new pot and a different waitstaff came by with another tin container of coffee, after waiting 20 minutes ( the other couple who was with us left because they could't wait for get a fresh pot. This second pot was also luke warm; The service has always been up to par until last night and the issue with the "cold coffee" and the original waiter never returned after the first order of coffee; so for that we were disppointed.
syee
author: suzan y.

description: I LOVE BISTRO AIX!!!  If it wasn't for the bitchy lady sitting next to me, complaining about EVERYTHING, I would have had a perfect streak at Bistro, but I won't blame this on them.  Reminder, part of this establishments name is BISTRO, so do not expect a Gary Danko experience.  Actually, this is meant to be a compliment.  You will find SIMPLE, beautifully prepared, delicious food at Bistro Aix - along with wonderful, perfectly laid-back staff.  I don't understand why people come to a neighborhood establishment in the Marina expecting a Michelin starred experience.  Personally, I like Bistro better than ANY Michelin restaurant I've been to - and I've been to several.  THANKS BISTRO!!!!!
author: Taress H.

description:
Very nice! Went here for a birthday dinner last nite and we sat in the patio with those little white lights...

Reasonably priced menu and we enjoyed the heirloom tomato salad, beet salad, thin crust chicken pizza and ahi tuna... not terribly crazy about the ahi tuna and wish I had just ordered a pizza like my friends, especially since it was $10 cheaper. For dessert we had the chocolate dream (dense chocolate cake that reminded me of a brownie with a scoop of ice cream) and strawberry crepes, if you must choose only 1 dessert I'd go with the chocolate dream.

Service was great and servers/host were very friendly from the beginning... if you're looking to celebrate a special occasion and want a charming restaurant without a lot of fuss I highly recommend Bistro AIX.
author: Nenette Y.

description:
I love this place!

Their bouillabaisse is to die for; comes with a FAT piece of sea bass & many many mussels...it's one of the entree choices on their $20 two-course prix fixe menu (Sun-Thur nights) which has to be the best deal in town. 

Their patio area is lovely - cute, sufficiently heated, and the starry night mural is a great touch.

Super-friendly staff; usually not too crowded on weeknights...makes for a nice night out in the Marina neighborhood.
author: Kathy Y.

description:
My fiance and I had dinner here last Friday night. The decor is super cute and I absolutely love the back patio. We also had really great service. The food was pretty good, but there was nothing that really impressed. 

To start we split the smoked salmon on potato crisps and the salad with warm breaded goat cheese. Both of them were solid choices and we enjoyed them, but we weren't "wowed." The salmon was good, but I suppose one grows accustomed to great lox when they live near Sables in NYC. I felt like I could make the goat cheese salad at home - it wasn't special enough. 

For our entrees we shared the pork chop and the leg of lamb. The leg of lamb is served sliced and needed more seasoning. It tasted a bit bland and I would have preferred it more rare. My fiance's pork chop was very good and super tasty. 

This is a great place to come if you live in the neighborhood. The food was high quality and the service was great. They have an awesome beer and wine selection too. Beware that the menu was very different than what was online.
author: Katie S.

description: Lively ambiance, great food, good prices, wonderful wait staff.  The meal began with bread and a fruity delicious olive oil.  Oak leaf salad with an incredible ramp dressing, and warm breaded goat cheese on greens.  Both very good.  Tagliatelle topped with coq au reisling.  Tender pasta with  crispy juicy chicken.  Gnocchi with trumpet mushrooms - great tasting but I found it a tad on the dry side.  3rd entree was duck breast which was perfect.  The tarte tatin was caramelized perfectly and the panna cotta with huckleberries was to die for.
author: Ash A.

description: Food was decent, nothing special...  Pretty standard stuff (had the steak, fish and a few sides). The big problem with this place, the service was rude and not good. It was not that the service was just slow (it was), that doesn't bother me.... It was that the waiter was actually rude from the minute he flipped the menus into our lap until throwing over the bill. We didn't take a long time and spent $200 for 4 people on dinner, there was no reason for the attitude. During the meal I let it go assuming he was having a bad day, however when his busser came over, I came to realize the attitude problem was not an isolated problem. My $.02, we're in a city with an unlimited supply of great restaurants - skip this one and try something else.
author: Jason M.

description:
The patio is really alot of fun either with a date or with a group of friend's.  The dishes are remarkably proportioned and I love the lamb, pork, or steak dishes here the most, although it was here I discovered why brussel sprouts can be healthy AND delicious...  

Oh but the creme brulee is what I am in love with the most - I wish I could take it home with me!!!  Like a neurotic lover, I can't escape the craving, not guilt, that appears the next day!!
author: Yelper A.

description:
There is a usually a reason that certain restaurants thrive.  Either the establishment is a tourist trap in an ideal location or it serves good food.  Bistro AIX has been satisfying my tummy for years, so I guess this means it serves good food.  I have never been disappointed by a meal here.  

Make sure you start your dinner with the calamari appetizer.  (I have no idea what the hell Asian Slaw is, but the squid is damn good.  The only slaw I know comes from Cole.)  Be careful with the delicious bread they put out.  You could easily spoil your dinner appetite by chowing down on the foccacia.  (Just like mommy always says.) As for the calamri, I think I have had this every time I have gone to Bistro AIX, and it has satisfied every time.  

The dinner selections are excellent.  The fish is consistently good.  On my most recent visit I had the gnocchi special.  Gnocchi is always a tricky gastronomical exercise.  It tends to fill the stomach to the exclusion of all other food.  Bistro AIX serves a perfect portion with peas and brown butter.   DEEEEELICIOUS.  I also poached some of the nettle risotto from my girlfriend's plate.  I would rank it as some of the best I have ever tasted.  

The wine list is extensive and it caters to a multitude of tastes and prices.  The servers are always very friendly and well informed.  My only knock on the place is the desert menu.  It falls a little short.  We had the blueberry pie special.  When I have blueberry pie, I want to taste the blueberries.  This concoction masked the taste.  Other than that it would have been a 5 star review.
author: Chris I.

description: After 2 years of living in the Marina this is still my go to spot.  Great to gather with friends, solo at the bar, date night, or whatever.  The food is fresh and straightforward.  The wine list is well thought out.  The staff treats you like it's Cheers!
author: Len W.

description:
Superb on food and hot bartender/ waiter Travis

Ladies, this is a must visit.  I was here Thursday for a business dinner with my friend Mary.  Alone I sat with a glass of wine and looked at 6'4 Travis; the bartender beautiful body and brillant blue eyes- a cute Austrailan import I think.  Ok enough of being an 18 year boy....

Aside from Travis, the food was some of the best I have had in awhile.   I am dieting so ordered the heirloom salad which was amazing!! The smoked salmon appetizer- came with somthing like hash browns which I unsuccessfully tried not to eat.  Mary tied me up and made me eat this ginger fig cake- yum- yum - YUM!!

Can't wait to return- definite 5 stars *****
author: rachel c.

description: 6 of us met here for dinner.  Excellent food, good wine.  We had Ahi tuna, Kobe burger, Pizza, burnt peppers, Sirloin steak, all very good.  Appetizers of salmon, salad were delicious .
author: Nigel P.

description: Came here for dinner because there was no wait for a table for four.  The food was good but not great for the price and the service was fine. We enjoyed the duck with pumpkin risotto and ahi tuna but it was expensive for what it was.
author: Lisa C.

description:
Love the outside patio, and I remember this to be a great place for an early dinner, mid-week, right after work.  Also, the waitstaff seemed really eager to serve me and my two roommates.  

Would come here again if I was in the Marina.
author: Katie C.

description:
I don't mean to sound like a snob because I was born, raised, and live in the city but the marina is a little on the yuppie side for me so I don't normally hang out there but I thought Bistro Aix might be a nice place to have dinner. Overall, I was underwhelmed. The question of the night seemed to be, Why?

Why did we not get seated until 8pm when our reservation was at 7:30?

Why were there a bunch of 30 somethings taking sexually seductive pictures in the patio against the heating lamp right next to our table? A new facebook profile pic perhaps? Hate to break it to you but sorority parties and college are over. Not cute ladies.

Why did we seem to have 4 waiters that night and why did it take at least 10 mins to get something brought to our table after asking for it? Our meter expired and risked getting a parking ticket because service was so slowww.

Why was there a woman singing "Disturbia" by Rhianna right next to us? She had a good voice but WTF?!?

Okay okay, I know I sound negative but on a more positive note, the Pizza w/ chicken was like being reunited with your first love. This made me happy. Ahi Tuna? EH. Burger? EH. Bistro Aix? EH.
author: Jen Y.

description:
My star score is more about the overall experience at Bistro Aix. The service only gets one star. The food perhaps a 3 star.

I always like to explore and try new things. I ventured to the City to celebrate and take my friend out for his birthday. Reservations recommended for sure. Parking is an issue since it's street metered parking and residential permit parking on some streets. We circled around a lot before we found a parking lot on Chestnut street. Give yourself at least 20 extra minutes to find parking if driving into the City. Also, bring quarters! We were about 35-40 minutes late for our reservation but the hostess was very understanding and nice. 
The ambience is nice, however the service was a bit lack luster. It could have been an off day for our server that evening... I say this because (1) our table was set for only 4 when we had 5 in our party; we had to ask for another setting (2) He never asked us for drinks or told us his name (3) When one of us asked him for a drink, he didn't think to ask the rest of the table so he ended up going back and forth bringing the drinks one at a time 3x (4) He forgot to bring Balsamic Vinegar upon request 2x (5) He exclaimed "Boy you all must be hungry" when we asked for more bread -- which you HAVE to request otherwise they will not bring you bread. (6) He never asked us about our meals or came to check on us.

Apart from the poor service that we experienced the food was good. It's not sharing portions but very fresh and delicious! 

I would still give the service another chance, it could have just been an off day for our server in particular. I made my reservation through Open Table and also called the restaurant to let them know it was a birthday, but nothing special was done, nor a Happy Birthday said by the wait staff or management. hmmmm. Makes me wonder why one should even mention "a special occasion". We opted out of having our dessert there and took our sweet tooth else where to celebrate the birthday portion of our evening.

From the looks of other reviews it's most likely we just went on an off night. I wouldn't mind giving this place another try because it does have a nice ambience and the food was nice.
author: Christine D.

description:
This place looks unassuming, quiet, and unremarkable from the outside - but don't be fooled - the food here is amazing!!  While everyone is oooing and awwwing over A16, Bistro Aix is being overlooked.  Which is fine by me, because I got a reservation that much easier.  And honestly, Bistro Aix knocks the socks off A16.

Between my boyfriend and I we had the crab cakes, butter bean soup, a pizza, the halibut, and a polenta berry cupcake for dessert.  Yes, we ate a ton, but it was the food's fault - it was so good we just couldn't stop.  We ate there a week ago and I still can't stop salivating over the halibut.  It was quite possibly the best seafood dish I have ever had.  Bistro Aix reminds me why I'm a pescetarian and not a strict veg - seafood can be effing delicious!!!

For the Marina haters (and there are plenty of you for good reason), this place is worth venturing into the Marina for.  All pretentiousness is left at the door.  Our waiter was great - attentive, enjoyable, and honest.  I appreciate a waiter who doesn't llllove everything on the menu, but is actually willing to correct potential selection mistakes.  Our waiter nixed our wine choice, and brought us two different bottles to taste before we picked the correct one.  And he guided us on our dessert choice advising us that the dessert we wanted appeared to not be up to par the particular night we were there.

I can't wait to eat here again - best service and food I've had in SF yet!
author: Nicole K.

description: A little gem in the heart of the marina, the whole feel of the restaurant is very European. I almost felt like I was in Germany, I started off with the butter lettuce salad and tarragon vinaigrette. I also added the goat cheese, the salad was fantastic, really loved the combination. Tuna was also awesome, the sauce was money. Great spot for a date as well, would recommended to all. I'll be back soon!
author: Jonah G.

description:
Quality, reasonably-priced neighborhood bistro.  Ate here for the first time last night.  The mesclun green salad with tarragon vinaigrette and warm breaded goat cheese was delicious.   My sirloin with maitre d butter, fries and watercress salad    was prepared just as I like my steak -- bloody as hell -- but somehow the flavor just didn't measure up to what I was expecting.  Also tried some of the lamb steak with rosemary jus and again found the flavors to be a little too subtle given the preparation.  

There is a good amount of breadth to the wine list, if not much depth, and the mark up is very reasonable.  

The staff was very friendly and quite knowledgeable, although they were pretty slow the night I was there.  I don't care if it's a busy Friday night, I shouldn't have to wait more than five minutes to get the waiter's attention after I sit down.  I'm hungry, and I want to order now! Feed me!  

I'll likely bump this up to four stars next time, assuming the service is a little speedier and my main dish does a better job of keeping me interested.
author: Andrew E.

description:
Setting is lovely. Service is top notch. I prefer grabbing a drink and apps at the bar with a friend over sitting down, but both scenarios are great. 

Food is good, I wouldn't say it was great. I've had the pizza, brussel sprouts, the fish dish & the avocado salad. Great wine list.

Setting over food, all in all B+.
author: Jill I.

description:
Bistro AiX is gotta be one of the best French food I've had with excellent price.  A complete 3 courses dining experience with a good bottle of redwine costs around 90$ ish?  How can you go wrong with it =)

The patio provides a very cozy yet exotic experience, definitely what you will not expect upon entering the entrance.  The service is attentive and swift, and wine recommandation is right on spot.

I feel they do make better Fish plates compared to Beef Sirloin.  My date had the Halibut (risky choice for first timer!)  and it was cooked perfectly.  The flavor was intact but never blend, and they went well with rest of the plates.  

I feel my Sirloins were overcooked that's why I am not giving it a 5 star, but the service, appetizers, wine, ambience easily make up for rest of the experience.

Definitely a great week night getaway!
author: Wei H.

description:
I read the Yelp reviews on this place which made me interested to try it. I walked in at about 6:30 on Saturday night and it was pretty busy which was good sign.
I ordered a glass of the Syrah which I found to be underwhelming.

My friend met me and we went to our reserved table in the back area which is an enclosed Patio. 
The server came fast and told us about the specials and was friendly.

I was absolutely starving and several things seemed interesting so I ordered more than I usually would have since I like to order small to get a sample of what the food is like.

I ordered the Argrettii, the Calamari with Red Pepper Alioli and Asian Slaw, and the regular pizza. My friend had the Oysters, which were one of the days specials.

The Argretti was intersting. It sort hard to describe what it is exactly it, but Wikipedia says "succulent shrub that is native to the Mediterranean Basin" It was interesting, but they prepared it with so much Olive Oil I couldn't really tastes the flavors of the vegetable

The Calamari was my favorite of the meal. It was pretty simply prepared in what the called a tempura batter, but seemed more like you standard Calamari batter. The alioli and the slaw were mixed in below the calamari. The flavors were very good and the dish and the calamari itself was a tender.

The pizza was just so so. I liked the thin crust but the ingredients seem cheap. The cheese was very bland and the sauce was a bit sweet. 

My friend's Oyster's where good, but there was very many. The corn dish that accompanied the oysters, was a bit odd, it didn't work that well. And for $22 it seemed very underwhelming.

As a whole, the bill was $82 before tax, for 2 glasses of wine, a beer, and one entree and a pizza, an app, and a side vegetable. Not insanely expensive, but for what it was a bit much.

I personally would recommend this place, but it keeps getting good reviews, so some people might like it.

If I had to redo the night, I would have waited to eat at Bin 38 where I met my some folks after this meal. The food there looked great and everyone I was with who ate there seemed to be enjoying there meal. 
Look for my Bin 38 review soon.
author: Ben H.

description:
I am waiting for them to reopen after the remodel. This has always been a favorite in my hood. The food (French) is always cooked to perfection and just slivers of heaven. It is hard for me to order anything else because I am craving my usual but I am never disappointed for straying to something new. (Try the smoked salmon appetizer)
The service is top notch regardless if your inside or outside. They know their menu and make great suggestions with wine. If they are not sure about it they find out quickly. It is always a romantic, intimate and yet unpretentious still very neighborhood orientated. I leave here feeling like I just took a mini vacation and a slight food coma.
author: Natasha M.

description:
Some may feel the Marina is just dudes in popped collars and women wearing enough eye make up to make one think a Maybelline factory may have exploded nearby...but there are some gems in the area - and this is one.

Menu is great, unique without being pretentious,  and they have a really good wine selection.  The staff is super friendly and knowledgeable. 

I had the Kobe burger topped with a fried egg on fresh baked Focaccia bread.  Lady friend had the duck.  We both really enjoyed our meals. 

Decent price, salad, two entrees 6 glasses of good wine and dessert was just a hair over $100.

If you're in the Marina, swing by for a classy meal, and then you can spend the rest of the night fist pumping at the clubs on a full stomach.
author: Cael G.

description:
this is the 2nd 3 star review ive had to give in as many weeks... i say that like its a bad thing and it is. When i eat out, i am hoping for a good experience with good food all around and similar service to boot. My friend Diana had wanted to try this place out for a while so we double dated (as we usually do) with our significant others! So read on for the nitty-gritty...

Highlights:
Ill start with the good... Server was definitely knowledgeable as far as options on the menu, mentioning items that were sold out for the night, and was very good with the wine selections/recommendations.
For apps, we had the cured salmon on potato galette and fried calamari. We ended up ordering an extra order of the cured salmon... the combo of the texture and taste of the salmon on a crisp potato hash was delicious. The calamari was decent enough... not overly battered or salted which some places do to hide the un-freshness of the calamari.
For our mains, my wife had the cracker crust pizza with applewood bacon, leeks, rapini and gruyere while i had the Kobeburger and Fries. The pizza crust was as advertised... crispy and crackly to the max! The flavor of the bacon really came through as did the copious amount of leeks. The rapini(a leafy broccoli of sorts) added some texture and color to the dish. My burger which was served on sliced focaccia was medium rare like i asked for, and was tender, juicy and flavorful. The fries were sliced both slim and thick with skins, just how i like them. These are both must try dishes at this restaurant!!

Lowlights:
Small pet peeve was that one of our glasses for drinking water had stains all over it including prints and lip gloss... i generally assume that this should never happen at any establishment that is presenting itself as $$ and shooting for 4 stars on yelp. What really drove me to give Bistro Aix 3 stars was the quality of the 2 other entrees ordered by my friends. Diana ordered the duck breast and her BF Will ordered the crispy roasted chicken leg. I found it amusing that crispy roasted chicken breast was also on the menu, redundant to say the least. The duck breast arrived overcooked, dry and was a tiny serving in general. Presentation was also lacking. The chicken leg was the same; the meat was dry and chewy. Not what we expected at all. Will kept complaining about the price as well $22... when he could get a better tasting and filling chicken at Costco for much less. 

3 stars for large disparity between items.
author: Denny C.

description:
$24 limited prix fixe menu Sun-Thurs, from 6-8

We arrived just past 8, so we ordered a la carte.  This place is LOUD and I mean SHOUT across the table loud if you want to be heard.  Super crowded for a Thursday night.  Full dining room increased my anticipation of a great meal.

I had the sirloin steak with fries and watercress salad.  My friend had the roasted chicken breast with red baby potatoes, haricots verts and jus.  Chicken was good, but my dish was cold.  Something about cold steak and fries--not appetizing.  Not sure if it was a timing issue, but I could tell my food had been sitting out for awhile.

It's probably a 4 star place, but my experience was 3 star.  Between the food and unremarkable decor, I wasn't impressed.  Read somewhere it's supposed to be one of the top bistros in SF, but I found the experience lacking.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Went for a very large party last night.  Arrived to an empty restaurant, and many other tables were served before us.  We haven't even rec'd menus.  I know large parties are difficult . . . nay, a drag; however, when everyone has arrived it's important to get out menus, drinks and appies ASAP.  We were starved so this didn't sit well with me.  Once we ordered, all went well.  I had yummy perfect steak with pomme frite.  Although I loved the steak, the fries were lacking, a little limp and definitely cooked (twice) the French way. 

Good food, reliable neighborhood joint, but probably would not go back.  The bf was very disappointed with the lack of full bar.  Made no difference to me, but if you are having a huge bday party as we did, it may make a difference to your guest.
author: A W.

description: Great tip from Raoul who recommended and booked this place. It was a Sun evening and Street restaurant on Polk was full to the brimm with a 1.5 hr wait! We couldn't wait and Raoul suggested Bistro Aix which managed to fit 5 of us in at the last minute. Great service, tasty food and lovely desserts. We had among us, the Cracker Crust Pizza with Tomato, Mozzarella, Fontina and Parmesan for appetizer to share and then Bouillabaise of Halibut, Mussels & rouille, Grilled Top Sirloin with Maitre 'd Butter, French Fries and Watercress, Grilled Lamb Steak with Rosemary Jus, Potato Gratin & Sauteed Spinach and Potato Gnocchi among the friends. Everyone enjoyed their dishes and for dessert, we had the panna cotta, creme brulee and rustic apple pie. Delicious and definitely an enjoyable evening sitting in the back patio.
author: Yan M.

description:
One of the few Marina spots I'll frequent...

It's got a pretty a good crowd, a good wine list and solid food.  Their burgers are really tasty (they're "gourmet, don't worry...) and the bread is delicious.
author: Alyssa W.

description:
YAY!!!!!!!

Sooooooooo happy to have Bistro Aix back in action!  

The remodel is AMAZING...don't miss the back patio!

The food is as great as ever - much of the same menu (i.e. BEST chicken ever!) and some fantastic additions.

Staff and service - friendly familiar faces!  

As good as it gets in San Francisco!
author: Lori W.

description: Wow! This place was amazing.  We walked in based off of the vibe, seemed like a good dining place with a wine bar feel.  We got seated right away even though there was a line because we were two ppl, and we got seated in the backroom by the tree with lights lining the branches.  It was very cute!  We had the grilled calamari on a bed of salads and greens and it was absolutely delicious.  We also had the squid ink pasta and the burger with farm egg.  I really enjoyed the squid ink pasta which was the right kind of saltiness and chili.  We wrapped it up with dessert with the chocolate cake.  All in all was a fabulous dining experience which was affordable $$.  I would definitely come back here and bring friends.
author: C L.

description:
I was in a rush, so I skimmed the reviews and saw the rating and booked a table.  Service was great.  Attentive.  Seating was on the patio!

However, I go to restaurants for the food.  The menu seemed more Italian than French.  The food was good, but nothing special that made me want more or to figure out the ingredients and techniques.  This would be a good place to take people that aren't adventurous.

Not my kind of place, but well executed for what they are going for.
author: H C.

description:
Great spot!!   The patio outback is the best place in the restaurant.   Went there on a week night with a reservation made that day and we got right in no problem.   We did the pre-fix which was a great deal for the entree and soup or salad.

The warm goat cheese salad was to die for.  I am still thinking about how good that salad was.   The sea bass was excellent, the light sauce was super yummy.  The waiter was helpful in helping us choose a good bottle of wine to pair with our meal.
author: Shelley B.

description:
Well I got 3 good things to say about this place and 2 bad things.

Good Things-
-Ahi
-Service
-Chimay

Bad Things
-Calmari
-Seat comfort
author: Mark B.

description:
First off, I have to thank the people who rate this place. That's how I actually found this great french restaurant.

In case you didn't know, my first experience with French Restaurant was surpass horrible. I was a little sceptic of trying a french restaurant again, that's how bad the first time was.( It scarred me!)

Exterior:
This is  definitely a lil-cute place, that you wouldn't notice from walking by. Plenty of different variety of restaurant on the block, sushi, streak house, chinese, sandwich cafes, and wine tasting. Plenty of people but "not so plenty of parking". Few shopping stores around the corner, gap, starbucks, chocolate shop, walgreen, bars, movie theater, and a few other little shops.

Interior:
Definitely a quite, romantic, candle light, atmosphere. Clean, simply, and nice for a conversation.

Services:
The guy who sat us, was super nice. He try to get us in as soon as possible even when we were late to our reservation. The waiter was awesome too, super nice and courtesy.

Food: The best part!!!!
Every night they offer a different menu. The menu was sooo delicious, every thing sounded so good. It was sad to only have two of people. 
We had the Pan-fried Pork chop, and the Bouillabaise Halibut. Omg, delicious is just putting it lightly. It was surpass delicious. We love the Pan-fried pork chop most. The waiter actually recommended to us, and everyone in the restaurant too. (He was selling that pork chop. hahaha)The flavors, the plating, the flavor (needs to be said again) everything was all there and on time. It was great. Loved it!
The bread and extra-virgin olive oil was a nice touch. (But don't fill up on bread, best is yet to come!)
Dessert: We had the Creme brulee, and a Tarte tatin. The tarte tatin is like a hot apple pie with whip cream, nice after dinner.

Price:
I wouldn't believe it if we didn't look at the receipt. Price was fastastically cheap, for a french place with great food. Two people, with dessert not one but two dessert only $60. French baby, French!

My Overview:
I am definitely going back, plus I will bring more people and sing about it to everyone. I'm no longer scarred by the mention of french restaurant. I'm cured! LOL!

One Look Out Point: No Parking Available Anywhere, go early.
author: Paulie L.

description: Bistro Aix consistently delivers the best food with a very pleasant and fast service. I have gone there for 5+ years and they never disappoint. Best dishes for me are the ahi tuna with spinach & mashed potatoes, and cracker crust pizza
author: Keval D.

description: Consistently has great food and service.  My girlfriend and I go here often and have never had a bad meal.  Last time I was there got a slow cooked beef short rib that was amazing.  One of those things you want to keep eating even though you are full.
author: Greg S.

description: The breaded goat cheese balsamic vinegar spinach salad is to die for. They have a good wine selection and their fish and sirloin are delicious.
author: Samantha S.

description:
First of all, the $23 pre-fixe dinner is really a deal that can't be beat in SF, not with the quality of fresh food you get at Bistro Aix. Ordered the bean soup which was hearty-yet-light, a nice turn for the magical fruit, as well as the bulliabase with sole, mussels, calamari (even the squirrely bits, which I can't help but enjoy) as well as an added surprise of turnips and garlic croutons.

Simple, perfectly filling, and worked amazingly well with the Vino Robles rose we brought with us.

My dining companions enjoyed the roasted leg of lamb on a bed of risotto (the most delicious bed I had eaten all day), the beet salad and the scallops (also on a delicious bed, but this one made of cornmeal).

All good things. The service was impeccable (thanks, GC!) and it was good times all around.
author: D. R.

description: Menu never disappoints.  A neighborhood restaurant with fresh ingredients and savory dishes.  A must go to if you are in the marina.
author: Samantha A.

description:
I stumbled on this place in a desperate, last minute attempt to find a rehearsal dinner location... one week before my wedding! Not that we had a rehearsal or anything, but I wanted a dinner the night before the big day for our close family and friends (approx. 32 people). 

Anyway, this restaurant really saved my ass in a spectacular way. The food was great, they set us up in a very cute and cozy private room upstairs, and they were located directly under the hotel we were all staying in (Cow Hollow Motor Inn/Suites). When I first saw the room, I was skeptical, because it seemed a bit drab in the daytime, but they made it so cute with candlelight and place settings, music, private bar, nice bartender, and great service. The person who coordinated the menu and details with us was awesome, too; never seemed stressed or annoyed by the last-minuteness of everything.

Wish I could say I remember specific food items to recommend, but I really can't recall. I think the salmon was good, though, and we did get lots of compliments on the dinner from our family and friends. 

I haven't eaten in the main dining areas, but we plan to very soon...
author: Jennifer D.

description: Had a great night here last night. We had the house cured salmon appetizer, fava bean ravioli, the chicken entree and the cheese course for apperizer. The house cured salmon on top of a freshly made potato chip like thingy was delicious and the raviolis were basically to die for. the chicken was cooked perfectly with crispy skin and sides (the green beans and potatoes that accompanied the chicken were a tiny bit boring though). we tried 3 different red wines by the glass and neither disappointed. the service was impeccable.
author: Yevi A.

description: Nice small place in the Marina. We started with the Asparagus and Copolla salad, it was delicious, but small. My entree was the burger (don't know why I was craving one) I got it with the egg and cheese, this has got to be by far one of the best burgers I have ever had, and I have had quite a few. I was shocked that this burger was even served here. Unfortunately they were out of duck confit, but the burger was excellent. My date had the spaghettini which was also tasty, but the burger was the highlight. Even the fries were so good! I will be back to try more goodies at this place!
author: Alex Y.

description:
While the food was very yummy and our server was very sweet and nice the pace of the service was the slowest I've ever experienced. We had a 6pm reservation which is early for a Saturday night.... that allowed us (table of 4) an hour and 45 minutes before we needed to head out the door. There were only a few people already seated. Well, turns out it wasn't enouh time at all... we had to rush our server to bring us our check without dessert. My husband is a huge dessert eater so not having the time needed to indulge was quite a disappointment.
I would like to give them another chance but only if I had three hours.
author: Coach R.

description: Easily one of my favorite restaurants in SF. Great bar and beautiful back area and the food is always fantastic.
author: M B.

description:
This place is a great little place to take some friends to relax and have a delicious meal.

Prices are pretty darn good for the superior quality of food.  I usually avoid any place with "bistro" in the name because they're usually some pretentious fruity nonsense with more style than substance but not Bistro Aix.  This place rocks!

The hamburger is just awesome!  Flavorful, juicy (even drippy), delicious.  The flavors just melted together.

The gorgonzola is a surprisingly good topping for a burger.  I think I'll use it at home next time I make a burger.  =)

I tasted some of the other food and it was just as good.  Lamb was cooked wonderfully and salad was excellent.

I highly recommend this place.  The atmosphere is classy but informal.  They have a great patio in the back of the restaurant where you can relax and have a superb meal while enjoying pleasant breezes, wine, and good chow.
author: Richard C.

description: I popped in here last Thursday for a casual dinner and glass of wine and was very impressed! The wait staff could not have been nicer or more accommodating. They sat us at a comfortable tall table near the bar, and the atmosphere was so relaxed and inviting. We ordered a glass of their Pinot Noir and then ordered the Beet & Goat Cheese Salad, which was fresh and delicious. We also got the spaghetti (or maybe capellini) with homemade tomato sauce and ricotta salata - again, delicious. Overall, just a lovely experience, I'll definitely be back!
author: Keira A.

description: This place was nice, good food and service. We sat in the front room and it was quite drafty and cold, would be great if they could make it warmer.
author: Kristin M.

description: Nice bistro in bustling Marina area.  Ordered: app - calamari, entrees - chicken, pochetta & steak, dessert - cloud chocolate cake.  All well done and service was top notch.  Nice!
author: Mario S.

description:
Wow! I really love this place. Just went there last night with my BF for a romantic date night and boy was it. The courtyard is so charming and I just LOVE the SF mural with the Van Gogh starry night surrounding it. The food was AMAZING. The service was perfection. I can't wait to take another one of my favorite people here. 

One more thing you don't feel like you are in the Marina anymore at all. Cool people and modest atmosphere. Loved it!
author: kerry L.

description:
We found this great place around the corner of another restaurant we left because it was too full.

When we got inside, the host took us to their back patio for seating.  It was a really good idea.. despite the cold weather, the cute enclosed patio was warm from the heat lamps and very cozy with the lighting and candles.

My man is a picky french eater and he was extremely happy with this place.  We had the tempura calamari for starters.. he had the red wine duck leg confit.. and I had the boullabaise.. it was absolutely divine.  Their fresh baked breads were perfect and we were totally waiting for more!  For dessert, we had the tarte tatin.   Prices were totally reasonable (unless you have a lots of wine like we did)  Parking in the area is tough, we parked in the residential area of the Marina and walked.  Noise level was low because we sat in the patio area.. 

It was a great meal and very romantic.  We definitely plan to come here again!
author: Nancy H.

description:
This is based off a single visit, so take that as you will.

I went here last night as I was on my way to hear Oliver Sacks speak at the Palace of Fine arts. I did a little research to find out where might be a good place to eat in the marina, and it looked like Bistro AIX was the winner.

I got in soon after opening, and it was pretty sparse. I had my choice of sitting at a table or the bar, and I chose the bar, because really, why bother with a table when you're eating alone if there is a bar to choose. I had the Prix Fixe (available Sun-Thur) which for $19.95 comes with a choice of soup or salad, and one of three entrees. I chose the soup, some sort of cranberry bean deal, and the roast chicken breast.

The soup was quite lovely - a smooth puree with earthiness from the beans, and some sweetness. It was garnished with a dollop of sour cream and some croutons, which really helped bring the soup together. The main course, a roasted chicken breast served with green beans and red potatoes, was also great. The chicken was juice, and the skin was crisp. The veg and potatoes were great too, but quite buttery, so how could they not be? Honestly, on the basis of the Prix Fixe menu, and the main food, this place is 5 stars.  I also had a glas of their Pinot Noir which was quite good, although not fantastic.

Well, it being the day before my birthday, I decided I would get dessert too, pretty much blowing the "holy cow this is not expensive" aspect of the Prix Fixe. I decided on the Creme Brulee, which I honestly thought was just average. The carmelized sugar top was a bit thick, and they got the creme part a bit melty from carmelizing it. Honestly, my gold standard for creme brulee is my own, which when it is on, is phenomenal, and when I goof up, still great. So really, their dessert is about a three. 

To sum this up, I highly recommend this place Sun-Thurs for the Prix Fixe menu. I am pretty sure their normal menu food will be great as well, and their prices are quite fair. But the prix fixe is a fantastic value for your food dollar. Their dessert is a bit lackluster, and it is because of that that I am knocking it down to 4 stars. I wish I didn't have to do that, but I wouldn't be honest with myself.

I'll go back here, if I am in the marina. If that happens, expect the rating to possibly go up, especially if the pre-dessert portion of the meal is as good as my first visit.
author: neil c.

description:
3.5 Stars

Good spot but it didn't leave me begging for more. The pizza with pesto and chicken was good, as was the beet salad that I ordered. Both were... good. It didn't elicit any, "mmmm's," or furtive glances across the table that would suggest we had just found a complete gem of a restaurant. It did allow us however, to have a good time chatting with good company. So that's, good....right?

Good.
author: Julia N.

description: I went Bistro Aix for lunch by my self and sitting by the bar wasn't a bad idea at all. Skipped appetizer to go straight to Entree. Thanks to that nice bartender, I had an amazing fish dish and a glass of good wine to pair with. Everything was decent enough for me to come back second time!
author: Tai V.

description:
Perfect! 
Like the drizzly, breezy night on which I ventured out to the Marina. Perfect like the movie I enjoyed at the Marina Theatre. Perfect, like the company I was with that night. But to truly understand perfection, one must randomly pick a restaurant (Just let that be B Aix), be seated in the backyard heated patio and order the most simple, insanely delicious and perfectly perfect plate of Spaghettini made with Ripe Roma Tomatoes, Basil Pesto and Olive oil. Perfect, like the warm, soft bread they serve. Perfect, like the most fantastic service that we received that night, that is oh so lacking in this city. Perfect like an extensive wine list, that one gets to choose from. I'm glad i found perfection that night. Perfect, like Bistro Aix. 

You get the picture.
author: Tushar V.

description:
I can't believe I have never been to this restaurant before!  They have a prefix menu that is available Sun -- Thurs. before 8pm.  Such a great meal for the price.  Phenominal steak & frites.

LOVED the back area seating.........covered ourdoor seating with heating lamps & twinkling lights.  Such a find.  You'll wonder why you never went before.
author: Wendi R.

description: This is a local neighborhood "Great find".  The service was beyond very attentive, the food excellent (try the Lamb meatball tagliatelle) and the laid back, non-stuffy atmosphere was totally relaxing.  Now for the good part - Someone (Owner chef and bartender) does a fabulous job with the relatively small, but really excellent wine list, especially the Rhones...wow, keep up this stellar attention to the wine details!   I will return here when in SF.
author: Andrew W.

description: This place was great! We called last minute at 8:30 on sat for 8 of us, so I was impressed that they could even get us in. Turns out they have a fabulous patio outside, great atmosphere! Food was delicious, I was very impressed, we had the crispy chicken from the recommendations of fellow yelpers and I LOVED it! We also had the asparagus and the gnocchi for appetizers which were both great as well. One of our patrons had the spaghetti which was great as well! Service was good and I will definitely be back soon!
author: Jenny I.

description:
Arrived for a 8:00 reservation this Wednesday and it was packed! Party of 3 and they sat us at a 2 top w/a chair at the end by the door and flanked by the bar. No problem. Server was obviously impacted and had a large station. She greeted us and let us know she'd be back soon. Soon meaning less than 10 minutes and I'm not exaggerating 'cause I was playing games on my Blackberry while my dinner companions talked it up. Also no biggie-she's busy and the restaurant is packed and constantly flowing with walk-ins.
We ordered the calamari with this fantastic smoky aioli and the beet salad with goat cheese. Heaven!!! The girls ate the calamari up and from what I could see of the remnants, there was a nice bed of vegetables it also sat on. It wasn't the traditional cocktail sauce and lemons which I appreciate. Bravo.
We ordered the seared Ahi, Sirloin and Pork Chops.  The verdict:
Ahi was flavorful, cooked just right, sliced just right, on a bed of mashed potatoes which was eaten right up.
Pork Chops and Risotto was so yummy! That mushroom risotto was just like comfort food and nicely complimented my rare sirloin steak. Mmmm...more arugula please!! 
The wine list is extensive and quite impressive and the wine by the glass list is also consistent. Get the bordeaux. 
On the downside though...no French Onion soup available during the busy dinner rush. Nothing really special about the service although it was quite adequate.
We did not order dessert but they did look terrific. After appetizers and entrees, there was just no room but next time. And there will be a next time.
author: Jessica K.

description: We had a wonderful dinner - eat inside if you like it loud (get a table in the front by the bar), or if you want a more quiet, peaceful ambiance try the back patio.  We got the prix fixe (offered Mon-Thur) which allowed us each to enjoy an entree and soup/salad for $1 more.  V's sirloin was tender and delicious, R's chicken was a tiny bit dry but in very flavorful sauce and the potatoes and green beans were very yummy. Unfortunately little room was left for the entrees because we both loaded up on the amazing bread in the beginning.  Two different types of glutenous, doughy bread are served with olive oil - yum!  We're both looking forward to finishing our leftovers tomorrow.  The polenta cake is a great way to finish the evening!
author: Robyn Y.

description:
I love the unexpected wonderful experience. Our night at Bistro Aix definitely qualifies. My friend and I were meeting up to see a performance at the Cowell and needed to have dinner first. A quick scroll through Yelp turned up this place. It looked reasonable enough so we thought we'd give it a try. Weren't expecting anything amazing, just a decent dinner.

We got so much more. We arrived around 6 on a Friday and the place was nearly empty. As a result, we were ushered to the back patio, which was already feeling pretty magical with the white christmas lights and heat lamps. They had just washed down the floor (which they do every day) so they gave us a table for 3 so we'd have a chair to put our bags on (including my hefty backpack). I was definitely not dressed for the place, but I was never made to feel like I'd shown up to the wrong place.

The service was wonderful. Our waiter was knowledgeable, humorous, and cute! He suggested a Spanish white wine by the glass for me (wish I could remember the name) and it was exactly what I described wanting (and was the cheapest on the menu - no pushy folks here). He also accommodated the allergies at the table by switching the cheese in our heirloom tomato salad (which was fantastic - a new twist on the traditional flavors with cucumber and olives).

The hit may have been the ahi tuna we shared. It was a simple dish, but the flavors really popped and the mastery of the cooking was evident. The spinach was delicate and flaky like seaweed, which in combination with the light and creamy potatoes and the gently seared ahi, was a comfortable, but decadent main course.

Couldn't skip dessert. The creme brulee is lovely (though almost outdone by the anise cookies that accompany it).

Go before the dinner rush and take your time. This one's a bit of a gem if you catch it at the right time.
author: Shawna S.

description:
Cozy and inviting, Bistro Aix is a nice, friendly restaurant that provides good food, fine service, and a great patio area.  The Italian-esque (but not strictly Italian) food is flavorful and good, and it is all reasonably priced.  My friend and I each got the 'prix fixe' meals, which included a soup/salad and an entree for $24 (versus soups/salads that are $6 and entrees that are $22).  The soup was quite good (cranberry flavored, but spiced right) and the halibut I had was also good.

Service was swift and a bottle of what on the table was quite welcome.  Overall, a fine experience.
author: Eric M.

description:
I went with a friend, and it took a while for us to get seated, but the wait was well worth it.

We sat outside on the enclosed patio area. The twinkling lights and wall decor made for a fun atmosphere. And the food was fantastic! 

I'd definitely come back.
author: Amy D.

description:
For my 100th review, it's gotta be someplace good. Somewhere I've been more than twice, and a place that is a treat to myself and the birthday/bonvoyage girl that always comes up from the peninsula to eat here on special occasions. Outdoor patio is heated, romantic but also great for groups, decorated with paintings, and the waiters are friendly enough to put up with my crap--"More bread! Put a candle in the dessert! Can you get us another bottle? Please split the check 10 ways..." 

The gnocchi never fails, those little morsels of chewy pleasure. I just want to eat them up! Grilled Lamb Steak is made perfect how the chef likes it and the wine selection always gets me in a good mood. The portion of the Orecchiette with Pancetta, Chili Flake, Baby Spinach & Tomato Sauce looks so deceiving that I can barely finish it. I've tried most on the items on the menu and you really can't go wrong with the ordering something simple like the cracker crust pizza or a burger. The only thing was that my beet salad was petite (it's french), so I got a side of garlic mashed potatoes. In this instance I was ordering less in my feeble attempt to get drunk and it worked!

Good times. Did I mention there's a wine bar next door? I don't know how good it is, but I'll have to check it out next time.
author: Kim G.

description:
Since we had such a fantastic time here last year, we decided to do it again - this time we had 27 people, same room.

I'm sorry to report that our experience this year wasn't so great.  The waiter looked unhappy and stressed.  I don't blame him since they ran out of everything - we had an agreed menu selection - but were not able to get everything on that menu.

Appetizers - they couldn't handle all the requests for the calamari - so some of our guests didn't get it eventhough they requested it.  Also, we had some late arrivers, and they didn't even get an appetizer - they were told they ran out.

Main Course - Steak was really fatty - heard that from several of the guests.  I heard good comments about the Tuna.

Dessert - I was very disappointed.  Me and my husband ordered the Creme Brulee - I was looking forward to it all evening.  When the desserts came, they plopped down a bread pudding which was not even one of our menu choices, and looked like a afterthought dessert - a cupcake with fruit on top.  They didn't explain to us at all why we didn't get what we ordered - they just plopped it down.  Needless to say I complained to the poor waiter and he said they ran out.  A few of the other guests didn't even get dessert.  I ended up getting the chocolate cake which was flavorless and dry....left half of it on my plate.

I heard about some other mishaps, but can't elaborate on them since I don't know the details.

My only guess to our poor service and quality of food is that they have either changed management, chef, or just were not organized that night.  

For $80 a head, it was a real disappointment.  We will most definitely be changing venues for our next year event.
author: Gina C.

description:
Bistro Aix was rather small and we were sitting really close to the other tables next to us.  We sat along the wall in the main entrance area, which overall is a bit cramped.  The waiters are all very nice and helpful with choosing dishes or drinks too.  

The bread was delicious, as was the olive oil that they serve with it.  We ordered the pumpkin soup and mesclun green salad with tarragon vinaigrette with warm breaded goat cheese.  The salad was absolutely delicious, with just the right amount of vinaigrette, enough to coat every piece of salad green, but not too much to overpower the dish.  

I ordered the grilled rare ahi tuna with wild mushroom/red wine sauce, mashed potatoes and fried spinach.   The portion was perhaps a bit too small (but then again, I'm capable of eating a LOT), but everything on that dish was amazing.  The tuna was perfectly seared on the outside and tender and rare on the inside.  The mushroom/red wine sauce was delicious for both the tuna and the mashed potatoes.  I've also never had fried spinach before, but it was crispy and much better than the sauteed spinach my sister had.

Dessert: we split a creme brulee.  The torched sugar crust was a bit too thick, which made it more chewy than crispy.  The custard itself was divine, creamy, and with the perfect touch of vanilla.  

Overall a great dining experience and I definitely recommend this restaurant!
author: Naoko M.

description:
Even though we had reservations, we had to wait a good 20 minutes for a table to clear.  When it did, we had the unfortunate luck of being seated outside.  The chairs were made of cheap aluminum.  On a cold SF evening, my ass didn't appreciate this at all.  The heat lamp wasn't heating up well, it was just plain uncomfortable.

The waiter wasn't educated about the wine list.  We asked for suggestions between two wines and he couldn't say anything about them.  He did offer to ask the bartender, but at this point, you could practically see him calculating the difference between a  20% tip and a 15% one.

For appetizer I shared the smoked salmon on potato galette with dill sauce.  The texture of the galette was nice and crisp, but overall, the dish was too salty.

For our entree, my friends and I all ordered steak.  I ordered mine rare, because I always figure rare at a restaurant really = medium rare ever since the ecoli outbreaks.  Um, no.  Rare = rare here.  It tasted good, but it was mooing and I definitely paid the price.  Quite literally, I got physically ill from it. 

We shared the chocolate cloud cake, which you would think would be either a molten cake or some sort of mousse cake.  It was neither: more of a flourless, dense cake with a crusty top.  It wasn't bad. 

But what I appreciated the least was the snotty look the waiter gave me when I asked for a nonfat latte with my dessert.  "We don't serve nonfat lattes," he replied.  Now, I fully acknowledge that after having steak and fries, appetizer and chocolate cake, ordering a nonfat latte is a bit like having a diet coke with your Big Mac and Super-sized Fries, but if you must laugh at me, don't do it to my face.

I at least enjoyed watching him mentally calculate the difference between a 15% tip and a 10% tip after that final exchange.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Great food and atmosphere, walking distance and centrally located on steiner street.
author: L. G.

description:
I really enjoy this place.  good food, comfortable atmosphere, and unpretentious... usually can get seated pretty quick too!
However, the service is not very consistent.
Look forward to my next visit.
author: shaun l.

description:
We came here on Friday of labor day so had no problems getting a table w/o reservations so I don't know what the case would be when people are actually in town.  Looks like you can order full menu at the bar though as an option.

The wait staff was excellent, attentive but not overly so. The waiter recommended 2 wines for us and brought us tastes. We went with a Joel Gott Cab and it was perfect. We brought a bottle as well and I don't believe we were charged a corkage fee since we had purchased a bottle, not 100% on that as I didn't get a close look at the bill.  We liked our busboy so much, who opened our 2nd bottle (a good Jarvis cab) that we offered to share a taste with him. 

All the salads and entries were solid, not spectacular but the quaintness of the restaurant really adds to the experience.  The only thing I wouldn't order again was the 'apple pie' it was not a true apple pie it was more like sara lee apple dumpling, heavy on the crust and light on the apples.
author: Sarah B.

description:
There was a weekend where I went to Bistro Aix for dinner 2 nights in a row...

Dinner on the back covered yard...excellent food, excellent service.  Might I suggest: 

Calamari (unique flavor)
Smoked Salmon App
Margherita pizza
Tuna done rare...

I have loved this place forever....will continue to as well!  They never let you down and somehow can always squeeze me in for a late weeknight or weekend dinner.  A city favorite of mine!!
author: Chris P.

description:
Aix is one of my favorite restaurants. They make classic dishes outstanding with fresh ingredients and perfect seasoning. The atmosphere is relaxed and the meal is not served at a frantic pace so you are able to actually enjoy the amazing food. Every time I am there the waiter makes excellent suggestions of wines that compliment my food beautifully.

Now for the important part: the food. The beginning of the meal starts with high quality buttery olive oil and bread that is baked fresh daily. The delicious combo of bread and olive oil is just a preview of the quality meal to come. The bread alone is worth dining at Aix. In my multiple visits, I have tried both the Mesclun Green Salad with Tarragon Vinaigrette and the Butter Lettuce Salad with Fresh Herbs salad. Both salads are delicate but incredibly flavorful. The herbs are vibrant and the lettuce is so fresh. Few restaurants can compete with Aix's simple green salads.

Each time I return to Aix I can't help but reorder what I got the first time: the spaghetti. Hands down the best spaghetti ever. The sauce has the perfect amount of garlic and is full of fresh basil and olive oil. I am always surprised by how good it is every time I order it. My meat eating dining mates have always been blissed out by their entrees as well- especially the Crispy Roasted Sonoma Chicken.

Writing this review reminds me that I need to go back ASAP.
author: Molly S.

description:
It's difficult to give Bistro Aix any better review than one star when my party was seated more than a half an hour AFTER our reservation time. I was upset and surprised when the hostess seated a group people ahead of us that had arrived at the same time without reservations. When we were finally seated, there were multiple open tables at which we could have been seated earlier. 
      I can't help but wonder what the point of making a reservation is when you are still treated as a walk-in customer and made to wait 35 minutes. The food was great but the over all experience was far too fouled by the unnecessary delay. In my experience, any decent manager or host would offer a complimentary drink, appetizer, or desert in a situation like this but no such accommodation was offered. No effort to make things right. This is supposed to be a Michelin Guide recommended restaurant? Seriously? I've had better service at Sizzler!
author: Joe T.

description:
We drove right past this quaint bistro on the busiest part of Steiner St.  between Lombard and Chestnut, and we were seated promptly at a window seat.  Nice clientel and sparse (in a good way) decor complimented the food, which yeilded only compliments (the ahi tuna is the best I've had in the city).  They did propmpt our meal by telling us that they were out of the lamb, calimari, and short on apple pie if they wanted us to hold one, so go early if you want the whole glorious menu.
Update: April 07, This is now my favorite restaurant in the city.  It just is awesome and low key and never fails to disappoint.
author: Moi S.

description:
"Oh my GAWD!!! It's sooo cute! I can't stand it!!! Oh my GAWD!"

Oh my God, indeed, lady. Could you please keep it down?! Yes, all these people - especially those in the back - would also like you to shut up now.

Other than that one evening where we were seated next to screaming banshee and friends, our meals have been very satisfactory. I love their chicken here. They just seem to know how to make chicken flavorful and succulent. Their butter lettuce salad is very tasty as well.
author: April B.

description:
I first noticed Bistro Aix when i was on my way to dinner at Isa a few doors down on the recommendation of some friends. I was curious so i looked it up on Yelp and found out about the two course tasting menu which is now down to $19.95 (from $23), you gotta love that. Shortly thereafter i saw that it found its way into the SF Gate Bay Area 100 list. I had to check this place out. Since moving to the Bay Area about a year ago, my girlfriend and i have found it hard to come up from the peninsula and really explore San Francisco just because there are so many options. Lately we've been hitting the Marina a lot and i've been pretty impressed. 

Anyway, i was a bonehead and decided we should go there on a friday, meaning that we missed the 2 course tasting, but fear not, we will be back. We ended up at a nice table for two on the patio right under a heater (which my GF appreciated). The patio was really neat, i thoroughly enjoyed it. We then got a basket of bread which was INCREDIBLE. There's a bread thats great with a hard, tough crust, but the gem of the bread basket is the super soft bread that soaks up olive oil like a sponge. It was hard not to fill up on bread. I also really liked having the euro style cool (but not cold, definitely no ice) water in a recycled, label-less bottle that we could pour ourselves. Its not huge, but it was a nice touch that i liked. 

On to what we came here for: the food. 

We started with the mesclun salad with breaded goat cheese. It was really good, but didn't blow me away. The goat cheese was obviously the star of the show. The crust was nice and crispy while the inside was soft, warm, and gooey. 

Next up was a special of roasted rabbit with carrots and morels. I think it may have been the first time i've had rabbit since i started really caring about food. It certainly tastes like chicken, though it has a more intense flavor and is a bit fattier. It was delicious and perfectly cooked. We got several pieces with the bone in, which made getting all the meat off without looking like a neanderthal a bit of a challenge, but i was up to it. The reduction sauce and the morels that the rabbit was served with were also incredible. I'm a big fan of morels. To me they have all of the good qualities of mushrooms (earthy flavor, etc.) and none of the bad (that gross spongy texture of your run of the mill supermarket mushrooms). Okay i guess they still look kind of funny, but i can get over that. The carrots were also incredible. 

Last up was their most popular dish, the crispy roasted chicken breast with red baby potatoes, haricots verts and jus. The chicken was roasted perfectly and was tender and juicy in the middle, but the skin was left on (and maybe it was broiled for a few minutes at the end?) that gave it this incredible and flavorful crunchy crust. It was easily the best roasted chicken i've ever had. The potatoes had kosher salt sprinkled over the top which created a kind of interesting (in a good way) crunchiness to them, without a dominating saltiness in the flavor. 

I was hoping for the apple crisp dish that i saw pictures of on Yelp, but it wasn't on the menu. Its okay though, we were full anyway. We will definitely be coming back though. I want to do the tasting menu and try a few more dishes that intrigued me. The burger looked incredible. The fries looked like they were super crunchy on the inside and soft and hot on the inside. It took lots discipline not to get a side order of fries. The steak frites also looked out of this world. The table next to us  got an order of calamari that also looked (and sounded) like it was great. I will certainly be back. 

Given the quality of the food, you can't really beat in terms of value.
author: Travis D.

description:
3 1/2 stars, but I'm rounding down since they were out of the dish that I wanted (seared ahi) and my wife wanted (pork chop).

Look peeps, I am NOT in the food business, nor is it my intent to open a restaurant any time soon, but how the hell do you run out of two of the dishes your server recommends before 10 PM on a Friday night?!?!

That being said, we did have a blast, the back patio was absolutely charming, and our server Corey was an absolute doll, I just can't get over this! On top of that, the steak that I settled for, was very tough (I guess you get what you pay for at only $22).

My wife's second choice, the prawns, were very good, no, excellent. And the two bottles of Willamette Pinot we put away went down great.

Still...MANAGE YOUR INVENTORY and DON'T RUN OUT OF YOUR SIGNATURE DISHES!!!
author: Kelsey G.

description:
Went here a while ago and it wasn't bad, but not particularly memorable.  

Atmosphere is a little cramped, lots of nooks and crannies they stuff people into.
author: Nate H.

description: Get the fried egg burger and substitute the gruyere for Roquefort. As the waiter put it, it will be "stupid good".
author: chris m.

description:
I had heard good things about this place and I was very relieved to have it live up to, if not exceed expectations. The tip to get the patio was great (thanks) and the easy going, just the right volume, atmosphere was ideal.

The service was some of the better I have received recently, with our waiter finding the perfect balance between being attentive but not pushy. Not easy so it was highly appreciated.

The food was great - the baked goat cheese salad was divine and the fresh bread was almost too easy to eat that we could have just had that. Overall I was really impressed at what we thought was an incredibly well priced restaurant - looking forward to going back,
author: Ben W.

description:
I've been back here a few times since my review and the food and the wait staff are consistently good.  They do steak very well.  
---------------------------
Cute little restaurant on Steiner in the Marina.  Good ambiance, good service, cozy atmosphere.  I ordered off the prix fixe menu (ends at 8pm weekdays, but the waitress let us order a few minutes after 8).  Sirloin steak and the cheeseburger with gorgonzola are both good.
author: Mitzi C.

description:
"Time/Date: Monday 8:00 pm

Type/Quality: Gourmet Americana.

Price/Quanity: $50 gets you two gourmet entrees, a glass of wine, and amazingly good bread. You will be full but the food is meant to be savored. We had lamb steaks and Ahi steaks. They come with various incarnations of tasty potatoes.

Service/Accesibility: The service was fast and parking at 8pm on a Monday was quick and plentiful. Its also a nice area to stroll through. 

Structure/Ambience: It has a relaxing romantic atmosphere. Perfect for a casual formal date. It has a warm interior and a patio area as well. There is an abundance of soon to be middle aged yuppies and people about to cross over that hill. Its still quite enjoyable.
author: Justin L.

description:
Service is first class here - I walked in a busy Friday night with my boyfriend knowing they were fully booked.  (we tried to get a space at the bar to eat dinner)  The host asked us to wait (to see if he could get us a table) and offered us complementary wine and beer!  Such nice people.  We ended up with a nice table for two next to the window, only after a 15 minute wait.  Yea!

The food was excellent -- the steak I ordered was cooked perfectly (medium rare), and the frites tasted like the ones in Paris.  One of the better steak frites in the city, actually (compared to Florio or Clementine).  I will definitely go back to try the pre fixe menu.
author: Lisa C.

description:
I came here for a friend's birthday, and my boyfriend and I shared a pizza and the bouillabaisse. The pizza was good with a nice crust, but the bouillabaisse was just okay -- nothing to rave about, and definitely something that we can make a lot better. I'm sure that they probably used a canned broth in place of a fresh one and frozen fish, which made us sad afterwards. 

The ambiance and decor here are nice (we sat outside in the patio area -- I think that's what it was), but I'd say that the service here is just so-so. I wouldn't really consider this one of the better French-type restaurants in the city. There are definitely others that are much better.
author: Yvonne W.

description:
For a mid-priced neighborhood restaurant, Bistro Aix is awesome. I would cross the city to eat here.

The first thing that stands out is that the place is clean, bright, and simply decorated. The second is that the absolutely delicious bread is baked on-site - an impressive feat for a small and busy restaurant.

I'm a big eater and my wife Brooke and I had plenty of food with a shared soup, salad, and entree. The soup, an heirloom-tomato and roasted corn soup with olive oil and basil, was incredible. 

I would feel happy eating anything on the menu - in fact, Brooke ordered all three courses. 

Kudos to the team for a great experience.
author: Christian B.

description: Delicious! Pasta was perfectly cooked. Very cozy feeling, we sat across from the bar. Reasonably priced. Wonderful service. Very classy!!!
author: Caroline B.

description: Just ate at this restaurant over the weekend with my family.  From the start I did not feel a friendly vibe.  However, decided to stay and give it a try.  The overall experience was mediocre, at best.   Slow waitstaff.  No water, tea or soda offers of refills.  Took over 1/2 hour to receive our entree's.  When they did arrive, they were all overcooked!   I will not go back, as between the waitstaff ignoring our table, the delay in receiving our food, and the fact every plate was over cooked, it is not worth it.  I recommend going elsewhere in the Marina for a good meal.
author: Sophia A.

description:
We sat in the back room under the wonderful skylight.  It felt like we were outdoors without the bees, bugs or cold.
Our salads, especially the beet salad was very good.  We had the pizza which was cooked perfectly and two of us had the spaghettini.  Normally that is not something I lean towards but this one was exceptional.
Great neighborhood place, decent wine list, and efficient and friendly service.
author: Carol S.

description: The laid-back, yet subtly hip ambience of this establishment is echoed in the simple, yet tasty menu at Bistro Aix. My friend and I shared the cheese and charcuterie, beet salad, and tarte tartin for dessert.
